passage: In ancient Greece, an Epicurean was a follower of Epicurus, a philosopher whose beliefs revolved around the pursuit of pleasure. Epicurus defined pleasure as "the absence of pain in the body and of trouble in the ______ blank that all life's virtues derived from this absence.
question_text: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

answer_rationales.A: Choice A is the best answer. The convention being tested is punctuation use between a main clause and a participial phrase. This choice correctly uses a comma to mark the boundary between the main clause ("Epicurus…‘soul'") and the participial phrase ("positing…absence") that provides additional information about how Epicurus defined pleasure.
answer_rationales.B: Choice B is incorrect because a colon can't be used in this way to join a main clause and a participial phrase.
answer_rationales.C: Choice C is incorrect because a semicolon can't be used in this way to join a main clause and a participial phrase.
answer_rationales.D: Choice D is incorrect because it results in a rhetorically unacceptable sentence fragment beginning with "positing."
